course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Contemporary Hong Kong: Government & Politics
course.description: By unfolding the multi-dimensions of Hong Kong 's political system, political culture, and political dynamics before and after its handover, this course aims to review the factors shaping the governance of Hong Kong. Throughout the course, intensive class interaction will be encouraged and multi-media teaching instruments will be adopted to stimulate learning.
course.exclusions: SOSC 1662, SOSC 1663 (prior to 2016-17)

reviews.author: Paolo
reviews.title: Best course ever for liberty loving Hong Kongers!
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are good in terms of knowledge, but B for organisation. The professor's lectures are too detailed you cant tell which points are important, it might be problematic when revising.

But besides that, its wonderful. The course perfectly explains why theres a lot of protests or riots and a lot of resentment against the government.

Content:

Lectures 1 - 4 are about Hong Kong government's legitimacy problems, an overview on why some people hate the governemnt.
Lecture 5 is about Colonial Hong Kong and why they had high legitimacy despite its non-democratic system
Lecture 6 is about the transition period from Colonial HK to the Handover
Lecture 7 - 8 are about Hong Kong's legislature and how it lacks legitimacy due to its structure and their collusion with big corporations (crony capitalism)
Lecture 9 is about the Principal Officials Accountability System, a system how the govt
Lecture 10 is about China's increasing control over HK since the handover
Lecture 11 is about the HK public's resistance over govt policies
reviews.comment_teaching:
Give him A for teaching. Professor Sing isn't only so passionate in his field of expertise, but he has a done a wonderful job explaining the slides and he's done so well in teaching without bias (despite what most might think). Sure its one sided, but all of his teaching materials are backed up with lots of statistics, public polls, and other empirical data. He also addresses and debunks claims from opposing side, so at least he isn't creating an echo chamber.

Best part is when relates the lessons to current news affairs.

Only criticism is he lacks planning. He spends too much time in the first few chapters only to realise he needs to speed up for later chapters.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Grade: A-

This year is special due to the pandemic and online learning, so the exam is conducted online. Not to mention, this course was taken after the National Security Law became law.

This year's exam was:
25 MCQs worth 60 marks in total
1 Essay Question worth 40 marks

While there isn't much MCQs, it will require you to think critically to get the right answer.
reviews.comment_workload:
Its very light workload. Only one exam in the very last lecture.

Honestly, if you're very familiar with HK Politics, this course is a piece of cake. I never take Liberal Studies in my high school, and i got A-

For the reading materials, prof said its required, but honestly there quite unnecessary as most of the info are already explained in the lecture notes.

reviews.author: akakakakakaka
reviews.title: A Course for Hongkongers
reviews.comment_content:
Professor goes through several significant social issues in details with the support of empirical statistics. Students may have a better understanding of the development and critical issues of Hong Kong politics. It is one of the most inspiring course you may find in UST. You will get to know why many people claim Hong Kong as no true democracy and how injustice our political system is. If you want to know more about the place you are born and bred, and don't wanna be a 'Kong Pig', take SOSC 1661.

I think it is sometimes too difficult for foreign students and also mainland students to take this course as they do not have a solid  ground about HK social issues, politicians and celebrities. It takes time for them to get these things recognised.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ming Sing is a professor encourages students to develop their ability in critical thinking. He, as mentioned in another review, has a very clear stance and he makes his opinions, if not findings, convincing. And, he loves inviting students to have lunch with him.
reviews.comment_grading:
You may choose to count all your grade on final exam (all MC) or writing an essay.

Final Exam is relatively easier and mainly require you to recall some hard facts, so it's more beneficial to hardworking students who go through PPT slides in DETAILS before exam.
reviews.comment_workload: What you need to do for this course is to be attentive in class and go through PPT before final. No homework, no assignment and no group project. Easy Peasy.

reviews.author: lmaoccc
reviews.comment_content: It's all about Hong Kong Politics. However, sometimes I would expect a discussion with more perspective cuz prof usually focuses on how bad the government performs, I would like to learn how to convince people that my thoughts are not biased and completely objective. Unfortunately, I think prof didn't include this part at all. So I would say that this course could be considered a history class or a TED talk,
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Sing Ming is very willing to share his thoughts on Hong Kong's democracy development. So maybe if you are interested in HK politics, you can ask questions and I believe prof Sing Ming would be very kind and helpful to answer you.
reviews.comment_grading: You can go 100% MCQ in final or 50/50 MCQ and essay (if I remembered right). For me, I all in MCQ and got around 34-36 out of 47. And my final grade is A, so I would say this course is really good grade as long as you really attend lectures and understand lecture notes well. You would still perform well if you already had solid background in HK politics. Based on MCQs are mainly tricky questions testing your common sense, being careful and sensitive to questions should get you a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Zero workload until final. Just prepare few days to study the notes well so I would say extremely light workload.

Best course ever :)))

reviews.author: Kabe
reviews.title: Zero workload
reviews.comment_content: Government and political situation in Hong Kong from colonial age to recent DQ.  Many events during different governor are covered, there are nearly 600 pages of ppt full of words and graph, and even those graphs are actually going to be tested in the final.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I only went to the first lecture and decide not to attend anymore as I fell asleep right away. He will play a lot of videos of different events in Hong Kong, which were quite interesting. However, his ppt is too wordy and I felt very bored reading them.

Also, he didn't release any details of the exam score but only the letter grade without any transparency.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 Scheme:
100% Final (59 MCQs in 60 minutes)
30% Short Paper + 70% Final
100% Long Paper

I choose 100% Final as I want no workload.
MC score is not disclosed. But I get A+ so I will say the grading is extremely good.
reviews.comment_workload: Zero if you all in final. No midterm, no assignment, no need to attend the lecture. Just recite (yes recite not revise) the ppt few days before the final and you will be good. But do not rely on the political common sense, do recite the ppt as the content is sometimes counter-intuitive.

reviews.author: kolhc
reviews.title: Decent course for learning Hong Kong's political development
reviews.comment_content:
I would recommend this course if you are interested in Hong Kong's political development.
The key topics covered in the course are as follows:
1. Human Rights - Freedom of Press Since the Handover
2. Quality of Life in HK
3. Political Participation - Party Development and Elections
4. Political Participation- Functional Constituencies
5. Debates on HK's Democratic Reform
6. Causes and Implications of the Umbrella Movement_Anti-authoritarian Movement (2019-2020)
Please read the course outline for more details.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor tended to spend more time on watching videos with the whole class (the videos are mainly from RTHK) and he will explain to you the idea of the materials in his powerpoints and what you should learn from it.
As far as I remember, 60% of the videos were Cantonese and 40% were English.
Sometime he might not have sufficient time to finish the lecture (mainly due to technical issues) and he would tell you to read the powerpoint yourself.
You need not to worry if you do not understand Cantonese as the content of these videos will not be tested.
Prof. Sing said that he will teach the course again in the 2020-2021 summer term.
Since it is a very popular course, you should enroll in the course ASAP if you are interested. Otherwise, you will lose your seat.
Also, I think we will not be able to see this course in the near future because of the political tension in Hong Kong and the fact that Prof. Sing is going to retire some time later.
Please cherish it while you can attend the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
One close-book final exam (counted 100% toward the final grade)
The final exam consisted of 24 multiple choice questions and one short essay type question.
You can easily answer some of the MC questions based on your common-sense.
The short essay question was to test your understanding of the course and how well you understand the required readings.
(not all topics will be tested, but I would suggest you read through all the powerpoints and the required readings before the exam).
reviews.comment_workload:
There was just one final exam, what more can you say about it?
I only spent one week reading the powerpoints and the required readings before the final exam and eventually I got an A.

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: A wrap up on HK political and social issues
reviews.comment_content:
I would say taking the course this year is a special experience due to the dramatic changes of the political environment in Hong Kong and the corona-virus which makes the content more all-rounded with more interpretation from various aspects.

Topics including:
2014 Umbrella Movement
2019 Anti-Extradition Movement
HK politics under colonial ruling
HK politics after 1997 (relationship with CCP)
Crony Capitalism
Principal Official Accountability System
Executive and Legislature relationship in HK
Democratization in HK and the World
etc.

The content are inspiring and I treat them as leisure learning without much pressure. Just be relax understanding and you will be fine. It is highly recommended to take the course if you want some extra understanding with minimal efforts and good grades.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures highlight the details from the notes and Prof Sing makes some interpretations and guidance on each topic. He also broadcasts some relevant historical videos from RTHK and other news agencies for further explanation.

It may be too rush for him to cover all the lecture slides content during classes due to time constraints, while each chapter consists of about 50 pages, which maybe troublesome for some students with limited background understandings. However, Prof. points out the key points for us to follow better, and indeed you will find the linkage between different issues, making the story-line clear.
reviews.comment_grading:
As always, a total of three assessment options are provided.
1. All in MCQs 46 questions 1hr
2. Essay 50%+ MCQs 50%
3. Essay 70%+ MCQs 30%

I choose the first option, which is all in MCQs.
Exam lasts for only an hour but the time for answering is very adequate given you have a general understanding. For some questions from the readings, I make some blind guess since I didn't revise all the details. If I can recall the details, then I can answer. If not, just guess.

Mark: 34/46

Finally get an A which is out of my expectation after completing the exam.
Nice grade and nice learning experience.
reviews.comment_workload:
Generally speaking, the workload is pretty low for a 3-credit course, you can choose whether or not to attend the lectures if you are able to handle the content yourself and make some background reading on the lecture notes provided. I personally skip several lectures but still that's not harm my understanding on the key ideas illustrated.

I started revising the lecture notes around one week before the exams, the key of success is to know the key-points and the key figures, the general understanding is important but not barely recite the content. I didn't revise the reading materials, although the exam includes several questions on the readings, but attending lectures and common senses help.

If you don't revise, Or else you will be like someone who always ruin his grade and yell wtf why you got nice grade all the time while complaining you are just a revision toxic jj, and even "someone" has taken the course previously, he can still think in an irrational way

reviews.author: purple
reviews.title: Light workload and good grade
reviews.comment_content:
The course was about Hong Kong politics

1: Human Rights & Freedom of Press since the Handover
2: Quality of Life in Hong Kong
3: Political Participation in Hong Kong â€“ Party Development and Elections
4: Political Participation III: Functional Constituencies: its Presumed Roles and Actual Performance
5: Debates on Hong Kongâ€™s Democratic Reform
6: Causes and Implications of the Umbrella Movement

Although the PowerPoint slides were not well written, this course was very rare in HKUST that offered enlightenment to students regarding the political issues especially the political environment recently changes a lot. Please do not think that you are not affected by politics. Politics affects the economic environment and our daily lives. In order to fulfil citizen responsibilities, protect our rights and enjoy the economic benefits, all of us need to care about politics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sing Ming has his own stand which spread the message that the period of colony was better than now as Special Administrative Region (SAR). I do not fully disagree with his stand. By attending this lesson, you should develop critical thinking and analyzing skills regarding the political issues. However, because I chose 100% individual term paper, I did not listen too much even attending his lessons :3
reviews.comment_grading:
There were three options available for students to choose how to assess their grades.
(1) MC 70% and a short paper 30%
(no more than 8 pages and double-spaced)
(2) An individual term paper 100%
(no more than 16 pages including references and double-spaced)
(3) MC 100%

I chose 100% paper and got A- for working the paper in few days without knowing the mark in the paper. I know two people got A and B respectively for choosing 100% paper. I also know somebody got A- for 100% MC.

There were six topics and one question in each topic. In short, there were six question could be chosen for the individual term paperâ€™ question.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was light if choosing 100% individual term paper MC. Slightly more workloads for 70%MC and 30% short paper. Compared to other courses in common core or major requirements, this course was heaven. I could handle it well even taking one English and one Chinese language course.

reviews.author: greentea0marco
reviews.comment_content: By unfolding the multi-dimensions of Hong Kong 's political system, political culture, and political dynamics before and after its handover, this course aims to review the factors shaping the governance of Hong Kong. Throughout the course, intensive class interaction will be encouraged and multi-media teaching instruments will be adopted to stimulate learning.
reviews.comment_teaching: Pretty decent for me. Mostly he is objective when teaching the facts and news article about the HK politics. He will also translate some terms to students if they are not locals, which is pretty nice.
reviews.comment_grading: You cant check your paper after the final. However i dont think its hard even if you dont read all of the powerpoint. Some questions are just common sense to HK politics.
reviews.comment_workload:
100% final MC or
100% Paper or
80% Final MC + 20% Paper

No attendance but you should attend class just to listen to him.

reviews.author: peter john
reviews.comment_content: If you want to have some knowledge of HK politics and society, this might be excellent to you. With large amount of information(especially statistical figure), at least you will understand some serious problem  HK is facing.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Sing's teaching was good, at least every local student could understand(I guess).
reviews.comment_grading: I dunno how Pro. Sing give grade and wt others get. So I couldn't comment it. Sorry!!!
reviews.comment_workload: There were 3 options on grading. You either wrote a paper, or only took an MC exam, or chose both. I chose MC only, with all content came from the powerpoint and required reading. So you just try to memorise the mainpoints before the exam and it was not that hard.

reviews.author: SBMKK
reviews.title: Light workload, poor grade, good for your interest and knowledge
reviews.comment_content:
As what written on the topic, it was totally for your interest and knowledge - you got lots of reading materials all written by the renowned professors and you will understand Hong Kong in a more dynamic way.

There are many aspects about Hong Kong including the housing problems, corruption, collusion and many other politics-related issue.

You will surely learn a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sing Ming has abundant knowledge about Hong Kong political dynamics. However, it seems that he didn't prepare much before his lecture and therefore he usually forgot which page was up to and he always repeated a lot.

Besides, he was quite busy after the Umbrella Movement and I guess that's why he didn't have a thorough planning for his lectures.

The first few lectures are quite easy to follow and with a lot of photos - but he used a lot of time to explain simple theories. The later lectures involved complicated theories and histories with lots of words in his ppt - but he needed to rush the syllabus - therefore there was not much time for us to digest.

Actually, there was only one plus side for his teaching, he had an extensive network and he could invite lots of guest speakers who had abundant knowledge about different issues too - and they taught better than Prof Sing.
reviews.comment_grading: It's for your interest not for your grade because of the format of the test and you can get a very low mark even if you studied for a long time --> see workload for detailed explanation.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very super light workload - only 1 essay and 1 final exam with all MC questions.

For that essay, no one knows how would Prof Sing and his TA marked but I guess they marked the essay very hea coz there are 3xx ppl attending the course and the essay counted towards 5 % only.

For the remaining 95%, there was only 1 final exam with all questions in MC format. One example of the question would be: when did former CE Tung Chi-wah have the highest supporting rate? There are a few choices but who would know?

And therefore, please do not aim for grade but learn in this course.

reviews.comment_content: This course will teach students about Hong Kong political situation after the WWII, mainly from the end of colony period till now. The information of the ppt will update to the latest. So it will include 15 year and 19 year social event in the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Since Sing Ming's ppts is very comprehensively tell us about each main Hong Kong Social issue. Therefore, his slide is quite long and always run out of time during lecture. We have to go through some slides by ourselves.

The course don't have midterm. Everyone all in final. In final there are 20+ mc and add one short question (40% of the final mark). The mc questions will ask you in indirect way, you have to look carefully. Overall the course workload is low.

reviews.author: stress+tension
reviews.title: Ok course. Ok grading.
reviews.comment_content: Mainly focus on the difference in politics and how the city is run before and after the handover of hong kong to china in 1997. Quite a lot of lectures are spent on talking about anti-government movements such as the umbrella movement in 2014 and the anti extradition law amendment bill movement in 2019. A lot of cantonese documentaries which are quite interesting in terms of content. However, some international students may struggle to follow the content as no english subtitles are provided for some of the documentaries.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Interesting content, but the prof was slightly boring.

Missed a lot of the lectures as they were quite boring. But from the lectures i attended, i could see that the professor has a very clear political stance (pro-democracy), but his teaching and content was not too radical so i thought it was ok.

However his content is quite unorganised and there arent very clear topics and themes for each lecture. The lectures consist mostly of him showing us videos/documentaries about the negative things about the hong kong government.

The main themes of his lectures is that authoritarian governments (e.g. china) are bad. As a local student, I find the content quite fascinating but I am curious as to how mainland students feel about his political stance and his teaching.

Hope his course wonâ€™t  be cancelled due to.. you know... meddling and interference... Would be a shame.
reviews.comment_grading:
quick answer - don't know. Decent, i guess?

No essays / homework
One online quiz (final) which takes up all the marks.
The quiz consists of around 25 MC questions and one essay.

The scores for the finals were never released so i don't know how i performed, but the quiz mainly contained questions that could be answered with a bit of common sense and a bit of revision.

I feel like the essay was just a test of how much english we could write.

Considering the fact that i did almost no revision (except for reading 2-3 out of the 12 required readings), im lucky that i got a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Almost zero.

There are 12 required readings involving 6 different topics (with extra reading materials for those who have nothing else to do). The exam will involve MC questions about the readings. But i only read like 2 of the readings before i got bored so the exam didnt go too well.

But only a fraction of the questions involved the readings so it should be fine if you don't have time to read through all of them (they are like 30 pages each)

reviews.author: Lyllyl
reviews.title: A good course to understand the political situation of HK
reviews.comment_content:
1: Challenges confronting HK
2: Umbrella Movement- a broken promise and new phase of democracy movement
3: Governance & Legitimacy Problems of HK â€“ its Past Success, Present Crisis, and Future Direction of an Increasingly Authoritarian City
4: Governance & Legitimacy Problems of HKâ€“ Drastical Decline in Support for Donald Tsang since mid-2008. Why?
5: Colonial political institutions in HK
6: Return of HK to Peopleâ€™s Republic of China (PRC) & Conflicts over HKâ€™s Democratization
7: : Legislative-Executive Relationship & Functional Constituencies
8: Business-Government Relationship:
Crony Capitalism in Hong Kong ?
9: A Deficient â€œPrincipal Officials Accountability Systemâ€ (POAS)
10: Elections, Political Parties & Executive-led Government
11: CE Election of 2012 and Implications on Hong Kong: Erosion  of Core Values and â€œTwo systemsâ€ in Hong Kong
12: Chinese Govtâ€™s Greater & More Obvious Control over HK
13: Attempts of Increasing  Control over HK
14: Democratic Reform for Hong Kong
15: Strategies & Democratization: Toolkit for Umbrella Movement
16: Outcome of UM & Prospect of HKâ€™s democratization
17: Post-UM Era: HK Turning towards Authoritarianism amid Beijingâ€™s Rising Political Control
18: A Resistance in Despair: Against A Turn towards Authoritarianism in HK
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Sing is very passionate in the politics of Hong Kong. He explained every topic in details.
reviews.comment_grading:
100% final exam
Closed book exam
MCQs and one short essay
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light since only final exam is required. There are 2-3 required readings for each topic and some questions in the exam are related to the reading materials.

reviews.author: juliawoo
reviews.comment_content:
The course mainly covers the major social and political events in Hong Kong from colonial period to the present. The content includes review of the change of social environment and quality of life in the past 22 years, the political and social environment  in the colonial period, the erosion of freedom in the post-handover period, crony capitalism, the executive- legislature relationship, political parties, Principal Officials Accountability System and some major democratic movements such as Occupy Central and anti- authoritarian movement.
I would say that the content is similar with the module 2 in Liberal Studies in secondary school but this course will cover more in depth. Many statistics and videos will be included in the lecture. The amount of the content is a lot more than the other sosc courses
reviews.comment_teaching: Although the professor may not have the best techniques to engage the students to listen to him in during the course and the lectures maybe are boring sometimes, but I think that he has put lots of effort in this course since there lots of content with a huge amount of statistics and analysis from different researchers. Lots of videos are also used to arouse our interested.
reviews.comment_grading:
You can choose from 3 types of grading methods
1. 100% MC
2. 50% MC, 50% essay
3.30% MC, 70% essay
I chose the first one and I got a pretty good grade despite many people say that choosing this method will result in bad grades. The transparency of the grading system is really low since I can only know my own marks of the final exam without knowing mean and SD. The first option is also really risky since the final exam only consists 47 MCs and your grade relies on them.
Regarding the MCs, some of them had some vague words which confused me. For instance, one option in one of the MCs is ' A large proportion of people don't support the campagin'. It is really hard to define the words 'large proportion' (50%?,80%?). The MCs also asked a lot about the information of the statistics. I recommend that you can study the trend of the statistics to better prepare for the exam
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is almost zero if you choose the first grading option. Just attend lectures and revise notes before the exam.

reviews.author: ls0207
reviews.title: Good course to understand more about Hong Kong
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into 6  modules
Module 1: Human Rights - Freedom of Press since the handover
Module 2: Quality of life in HK
Module 3: Political Participation - Party development and elections
Module 4: Political Participation - Functional Constituencies
Module 5: Debates on HK's democratic reform
Module 6: Causes and implications of Umbrella movement/ Anti-authoritarian movement
with some examples, theories, and research on democracy and politics is covered in this course
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Sing has a sleepy tone and he speaks quite slow with a quite objective view, but he raised a lot of findings, examples, and theories to supports his point of view. He himself is a supporter of the traditional pro-democracy camp ( left-plastic) but even you ask some questions that challenging the democrats, he still willing to answer you.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 grading scheme:
1. 100% all-in final exam ( 45-60 mc, 47 questions this time)
2. 50% final exam + 50% 10-pages short paper
3. 30% final exam + 70% 15-pages long paper

I want no workload so that I opt for option 1. For people who choose option 1, the grades will be so extreme that most of them are either A or C while writing papers will get a safe grade easier.
The scores for the exam are not disclosed in the previous years but this is the first year to disclose it.

I got an A- by getting 33/47 in the final
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light for option 1, but you still need to keep yourself familiar with the lecture notes and readings in order to handle the exam. Better handle the  materials earlier so that you have sufficient time to read all the materials and won't be so "chur"

reviews.author: ahtp
reviews.comment_content: The content is rich and interactive. Professor Sing will broadcast documentaries during lectures from time to time. He intended to cover and compare our society and political system between past and present in spite of insufficient time. The content, however, is not near to impartial whatsoever which, I believe, could have been done better.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Sing tries to teach as much as he can, but it is unfortunate that he was unable to manage the time well. His presentations nor lectures are systematic nor easy to follow. He would have become an even better instructor should he had taught the course more objectively, in spite of his enthusiasm for teaching and commitment to  pursuing a more democratic Hong Kong.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is quite lenient in my view. I didn't revise the last few presentation slides and thought I would underperform. I rarely jotted notes. I was surprised that I have got an "A" at last.
reviews.comment_workload: I opted for "MC exam + Pop-up quiz". I revised the whole course just a day before the exam. I feel that it is not challenging to master the course provided that you have always been aware of local affairs and problems, and possessed a good memory. It is crucial to go over the graphs and understand the trends. Reciting presentation slides is equally important.

4. Past aborted democratization before 1997: Role of the public, democracy
movement, Beijing and London.
5. Executive and legislative branch: Why has there been a high degree of tension
since the handover? Empirical Assessment of Performance of Functional
constituencies: should they be maintained?
6. Political parties and elections â€“ main features in a hybrid regime?
7. Discussion of some of the following challenges for Donald Tsangâ€™s / CY Leungâ€™s
regime
i. Is there government-business collusion in HK?
ii. Rising income inequality â€“ political implications
iii. Freedom of press under threat?
iv. Debate and Conflict over express rail / moral and national education:
implications?
v. Younger generation, social movements & Hong Kong politics: causes,
nature and strategies.
vi. China-Hong Kong tensions.
8. Changing political culture: a new generation?
9. Civil society and political mobilization
10. Debate on democratic reform: should universal suffrage be implemented as soon
as possible? Is Hong Kong ready for it?
11. Causes of the Umbrella Movement
12. New Political Development after the Umbrella Movement

reviews.author: Kelvin Y
reviews.title: No workload, ok grading
reviews.comment_content:
Just need to read the lectures and memorise as much as you can. Lecture notes are quite long though, so it's best not to rush it all at once.
There are other reading materials to read if you really want to ace the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Only went to one lesson, didn't really help for me. I would recommend reading the lecture notes yourself and try to remember as much as you can.
reviews.comment_grading: Ok grading, considering the amount of effort I put into it.
reviews.comment_workload:
100% of your marks are based on the final exam, all multiple choice.
No midterm, no assignments,

reviews.author: Jacek. CH
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly focused in how Hong Kong was governed and what were the consequences that brought by different governing style/policy.

You will first learn how Hong Kong was governed in colonial time. Then move forwards to the governance of the past three Chief Executives with the Umbrella Movement as the last part of the course.

The professor has a very clear stand. If you are very sensitive to this(especially mainland students or pro-establishment), then probably you should not take this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is really boring and the professor always spend time to ask people stop talking.

Sometimes the professor invited guests to give speech. Some of them are worth listening.
reviews.comment_grading:
Transparency is extremely low.
You may either choose all in final or write an essay, or combining these two.

I chose all in final, and the professor didn't tell us our score. But I eventually got an A so I think its fair enough given that I almost skipped every lesson throughout the semester and just skimmed through all lecture notes before taking the exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light. No projects, assignments.
There is only a final, or an essay if you choose it.

However, the final is very difficult. The questions were hardly related to course content. Only few of them I could trace back to the lecture notes. So basically everyone are doing the final with common sense. If you are very familiar with Hong Kong's politics or very good at liberal studies, then you are all fine.

reviews.author: justinho11
reviews.comment_content: Contents are easy and understandable which are mostly about current HK political trend and situation. Most of the content is common sense, local student should be easy to handle while non local student can have an in depth understanding towards HK politics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Sing Ming is obviously a pro democratic the teaching is a bit biased. The lectures is kinda boring, attendance is not required, therefore the lecture hall is only 1/3 filled
reviews.comment_grading: all in final,revising the powerpoint just two days before the final exam, get a B
reviews.comment_workload: 0 workload,  only revise the ppt slides is ok, even though there are a lot of readings,

reviews.author: Davidwong
reviews.comment_content: Interesting topic about HK politics, including issues since 1950s. E.g. SARS, Universal suffrage, Umbrella revolution
reviews.comment_teaching: Most of the time, Sing Ming speaks bilingually. Not an easy course for foreigners and non-local students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Most of the stedents who attempted the exam got C range.
Also, Sing Ming does not announce the result of final exam, and you can only know your grade through student centre.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload if you choose to attempt the MC exam, which includes 55 Multiple choice question and you have to finish it in 50 minutes.

reviews.author: edwinbg
reviews.comment_content:
A summary of HK politics.
I think every year the content of this course will change, it choose the hottest topic to teach.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teacher is like a high school teacher. You cant talk in the class or he would shout at you.
He is caring his student, he would has lunch with student.
reviews.comment_grading: I choose to write essay but not mc. I only use 1 night to finish and have a B+. I think write essay would be easily to get high marks.
reviews.comment_workload: There are very low workload. You no need to join any class and read the powerpoint but you can still finsh the course and get a good marks.

reviews.title: zero workload, good introductory course
reviews.comment_content: A very good course for locals (or for those who understand Cantonese) to understand more about what the government is doing behind the scene. Increase your political awareness. Know more about Hong Kong.
reviews.comment_teaching: The slides suck. Unorganized, lots of formatting errors. Don't expect too much in-class. But those videos are worth to watch.
reviews.comment_grading: I have spent all my time to read all the materials and slides. I dont even get into A range. The grading system is ridiculous.

reviews.comment_content:
Main point: Democracy!!!
Good for people who want to know more about Hong Kong's politics, especially after the Umbrella Movement.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think he had done a good job in teaching politics, and he could provide a lot of useful information about different important events happened in Hong Kong.
reviews.comment_grading: B- with watching some of the videos, several pages of readings, and all of the PPTs. Didn't listen to him for most of the time...

Low.
Although there are many PPTs and assigned readings to read, and also a number of videos, they seems like to be useless in the exam...So it could be low if you don't read or watch all of the materials.

reviews.author: Ga Yan
reviews.title: Expands your knowledge, great workload, but too lecture orientated
reviews.comment_content:
- just 1 MCQ exam at the end and 1 essay, lots of readings but no quizzes
- I really found out more about HK politics eg the way the constituents work so for me this course was successful
- the readings were well chosen and interesting
- the theory and content is very easy to grasp
- attendance not counted but exams based on lecture material as well as readings
reviews.comment_teaching:
- Too lecture orientated, we literally just sat and listened for 1.5 hours (this is a problem with most UST courses), not much discussion a lot of watching/listening instead.
- Difficult for non-chinese speakers (when I took this there were around 10 non-chinese taking the course) to keep up when the lecture stopped and videos were shown but it didn't affect my grade too much
- incorporation of guest speakers and guest events was good, we got to see other perspectives and voices regarding HK governance and it made the course more interesting
reviews.comment_grading:
- Make or break exam at the end - we had 38 MCQs that determined 95% of your grade.
- 5% was for a reflective essay, since it's reflective it's not intense/research heavy and so it's easy to write and do well in.
- Very generous grading, hard to get D's.
reviews.comment_workload:
- quite a lot of reading to do, but you can get away with cramming at the end (of course that's not the best way if you really want to learn but if you're just in the course for a good grade, there you go)
- as a result of barely any exams, workload is very good, you can sit and enjoy the lectures and learn what you want for the first 10 weeks or so.

reviews.author: Hin
reviews.title: Contemporary HK
reviews.comment_content: Political affairs around HK. From Tung Chee-wah, Donald Tsang to CY Leung and Umbrella Movement.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof is teaching quite good because he has profound knowledge about this aspect. But it seems he didn't have well planning about the course, i.e. teaching time is not equal for each topic.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is bad because 95% of grade comes from the final exam, which only consists of 32 MCQs. 5% from essay writing. You can gain that 5% as far as you have finished and submitted. Because of the 95% final exam, if you wrong for 2 MCQs, you already give up a grade (not a sub-grade).
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is the most enjoyable throughout my study in UST. No mid-terms and homework assignments. Weekly assigned readings and only one essay. And actually, the assigned readings are not directly tested in exam, so no need to read at all.

reviews.author: tm498
reviews.comment_content:
1. Anti-government protests in Hong Kong: Causes and Effects
2. Challenges to governance & Quality of Life in Hong Kong since 1997: A snapshot review of Hong Kongâ€™s past 23 years since the handover.
3. Past model of economic and political development before 1997: Why was legitimacy problem less obvious than the post-handover period? Can the past model still work for the post-handover Hong Kong?
4. Past aborted democratization before 1997: Role of the public, democracy movement, Beijing and London.
5. Executive and legislative branch: Why has there been a high degree of tension since the handover? Empirical Assessment of Performance of Functional constituencies: should they be maintained?
6. Political parties and elections â€“ main features in a hybrid regime?
7. Discussion of some of the following challenges for Donald Tsangâ€™s / CY Leungâ€™s regime
i. Is there government-business collusion in HK?
ii. Rising income inequality â€“ political implications
iii. Freedom of press under threat?
iv. Debate and Conflict over express rail / moral and national education: implications?
v. Younger generation, social movements & Hong Kong politics: causes, nature and strategies.
vi. China-Hong Kong tensions.
8. Changing political culture: a new generation?
9. Civil society and political mobilization
10. Debate on democratic reform: should universal suffrage be implemented as soon as possible? Is Hong Kong ready for it?
11. Causes of the Umbrella Movement /Anti-authoritarian Movement (2019-2020)
12. New Political Development after the Umbrella Movement /Anti-authoritarian Movement (2019-2020)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Terrible. No class interaction. Professor did not answer questions in class (could hardly use zoom). Did not give us necessary information about the final. Used class time to show a lot of videos in chinese with chinese subtitles. Biased and one-sided view of politics. No depth/complexity explored.

Then got annoyed that only 1/3 of the class was attending lectures so he stoped recording them (no big loss for students given the quality of his lectures).
reviews.comment_grading:
100% Final Exam
Includes MCQ and one essay

Professor would not tell us what % was MCQ and what % was essay or even how many questions there were.
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload as there are no projects/presentations. Just need to work hard towards the end of semester.

reviews.author: a.stupid
reviews.title: Passionate professor, Great course content, Bad exam/assesment
reviews.comment_content:
Contemporary Hong Kong politics. You can find detailed reviews in other comments so I won't add much color to this section.

Every Hongkonger should take this course in my opinion, it provides you an answer to why Hong Kong has evolved in today's situation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Sing Ming is no doubt one of the best professors in Hong Kong politics. He is very passionate and knowledgeable in this field.

Local students may think he is to moderate, while mainland Chinese students may think he is too extreme. But both sides would agree that Prof. Sing Ming has provided solid evidence in explaining his argument, and is able to present the argument in a logical and reasonable way.

He provides detailed PPT, readings, and relevant videos to foster students' understanding of contemporary Hong Kong politics. These materials are very well prepared and you are suggested to go through them during the semester to gain a solid understanding of the topic.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolutely no data is disclosed. Students will not know their final score, mean, SD, etc. That's not really democratic considering the professor's stance.

Just to give you guys a rough estimation, there are 46 MC questions in the final exam. I am confident that I answered 36 questions correctly. For the other 10 questions, I believe I have a 50-50 chance to get the correct answer.

Final Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
I skipped all the lectures during the semester. Never revised or read any course materials during the semester.

However, I did spend 7 days to watch all the lecture videos and read all the lecture PPTs before the exam (but didn't review the readings at all).

reviews.author: Kitty Leung
reviews.title: Short review summary
reviews.comment_content: Structured content notes and topics are related to Liberal Studies in high school, so can relate concepts and examples learnt before. Also, most issues were happened in Hong Kong, that enhance the familarity of it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good teaching with the use of relevant video clips that helps increase understanding of the topic.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is mysterious as some students get A range but some get C range.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload, only 5% essay and 95% MC final. But the final is not held in the final exam period but before it, so there is less time to revise and prepare for it.

reviews.author: graceltw
reviews.comment_content:
Very rich if you want to learn about the history & political background of Hong Kong. It gives you a thorough understanding of why Umbrella Movement happens, what happened during Tung Chee-wah, Donald Tsang, and CY Leung that caused Hong Kong people's dissatisfaction. Locals might have certain advantage as we would have heard of most of the event mentioned, but it is definitely worth for non-locals or mainland students to learn more about it if you want to know more about Hong Kong, particularly from a democratic standpoint.

There are 2 readings per week, but sometimes they will repeat what is taught in the lecture. If you want to learn more about democracy, change and Hong Kong, definitely read them and the optional reading, you will learn a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Sing is a very prominent figure among democrats in Hong Kong and you will definitely learn a lot from him if you take his course. I would not deny his teaching is sometimes biased at some point, so you would need to think critically and independently, but he often back up his arguments with examples and clear logic flow.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite good. However, since there are only 30 something MCs in the final exam, you may get one subgrade lower simply by getting 1-2 questions wrong.
reviews.comment_workload: Extremely light with just a reflection essay (5%) and a final exam (95%). The final exam was done inside LT-A during class hour, so you don't have to worry about the course during the final exam period.

reviews.author: TCheung
reviews.comment_content: Simple discussion on the political system and culture of Hong Kong, for instance, the electoral system. Some current news is mentioned too, such as the umbrella movement.
reviews.comment_teaching: It will be quite boring if you are not interested in politics. Besides, Prof. Sing Ming dislikes people talking during lectures, he will ask you whether you have any to share if you talk.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam (ALL MC) 95%
Short Reflective Paper 5%

Should not be difficult to have a B range, given that you study hard, however, the exam arrangement was problematic that there was no seating plan while 400 people were fully sat in the LT-A. As a result, many people cheated in the final.

I did moderate revision and did not cheat, finally got C+. No paper checking, and you even don't know what marks you got.
reviews.comment_workload: If you follow his instructions, i.e. read all the required readings, the workload is fairly high. Otherwise, like many people, the workload is almost none, but probably will not get a good grade unless cheat.

reviews.author: TheTurtle
reviews.comment_content: A rather comprehensive course about the whole Hong Kong political system. Talks about anything from Chief Executives to Legislative Council to the Umbrella Movement. Good for students eager to know more about the Hong Kong political mechanism.
reviews.comment_teaching: Not too good. Professor is biased. Although I personally agree with most of his views he does not provide a fair and impartial analysis of political events. Most of the time he is very anti-government and he voices it out openly. Curriculum planning is not done properly. Some materials are covered way too in depth while others are shallow. He also seems much more interested and involved in his work promoting his views in the society (newspaper columns, interviews, protests etc) than in teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: Not good. 95% of the grade is covered in an MCQ-only final. There are no past papers provided so you have no idea what is going to be tested. Pretty much a complete gamble.
reviews.comment_workload: Very little workload. There are papers which would enhance your understanding if you read them. There is one essay which accounts for 5% of your final grade and that's it.

reviews.author: Stella
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly common sense things to local students.
Every week got 2 pieces of reading materials, they will only be tested on final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher seemed to brainwash students by always revealing the dark side of governments. Other things are fine for me.
reviews.comment_grading:
Easy to get good result if you work hard 3 days before the exam even if you often skip lesson.
But you only got one chance, the final exam is heavily weighted.
reviews.comment_workload:
Nearly no workload.
Only a piece of essay at the end but it only counted 5%
